Introduction to R
R is one of the most commonly used programming languages in statistics and data science, and if youâ€™re planning to explore data science at Wellesley, you will encounter R in many of your classes. This guide will help you get started with the basics of R and RStudio!

ðŸ’­ When and why was R made? Who contributed to the development of this language?

R was created by statisticians Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman in 1993 in order to teach introductory statistics courses at the University of Auckland. R built on another statistical programming language, S. From its inception, R has been a free, open source language meaning that anyone can use and modify the language.

The Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) was founded in 1997 by Kurt Hornik and Fritz Leisch to host user packages, source code, and documentation. One of Râ€™s most powerful tools is the ability to easily download and use packages other users have made for any sort of statistical analysis you may need. As a result, Râ€™s development has been thanks to a large community of R programmers and users.

ðŸ“— What classes at Wellesley use this language?

At Wellesley, the primary classes that use R are in the STAT/QR department:

  • STAT160 Fundamentals of Statistics
  • STAT218 Introductory Statistics and Data Analysis
  • STAT228 Multivariate Data Analysis
  • QR / STAT260 Applied Data Analysis and Statistical Inference
  • STAT318 Regression Analysis and Statistical Models

ðŸ’» Best IDEs for this language?

You can use R and the R console directly, but if you'd prefer another user interface then the most commonly used and popular IDE for R is RStudio, an IDE created by Posit. After downloading R, you can download desktop RStudio for free here. RStudio is recommended for beginner users of R and has a very user friendly interface. You also have access to lots of developer support.

Another option for an IDE is JupyterLab, which integrates with both R and Python, so it's a helpful IDE if you want to use both languages at the same time. If you're more familiar with Python for data analysis, then this is a helpful IDE to use. However, it is not as beginner friendly as RStudio and lacks some of the same convenient features. JupyterLab is available to download here. For those with a Windows operating system, you may also consider R Tools for Visual Studio, which was built by Microsoft for Windows specifically. However, like JupyterLab, it may lack some of the same features as RStudio. You can add R Tools to Visual Studio using this link.

ðŸ“Š What can you build with this language?

  • Statistical inference and research â€” R has many built in functions specifically for statistical analysis, including different hypothesis tests and probability distributions.
    • Calculations on matrices and arrays â€” In addition to basic calculations, you can also utilize built-in programming functions that will be familiar from other languages, including for loops, conditionals, recursive functions, and input and output facilities.
    • Machine learning algorithms â€” You can train and test different models and compare their accuracy for machine learning purposes.
  • Visualizations and statistics related graphics â€” A primary reason data scientists like to use R is because of its ability to easily create informative graphs within R itself.

ðŸ¤” Where can students go to find further information / resources on this language?

  • CRAN â€” Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN), get information about documentation and any updates to the R language
  • Tutorial: Getting Started with R and RStudio - Dataquest â€” Introduction to using RStudio specifically
  • Rseek â€” Search engine for everything related to the R language
  • R for Data Science â€” Online textbooks for learning R in the context of data science, super helpful for beginners
  • base R cheat-sheet â€” R beginner cheat sheet with many of the most common functions listed out
  • RStudio Cheatsheets â€” Other cheat sheets for more advanced R functions
  • The R Graph Gallery â€” R graph and visualization inspiration
